displayed_text: Family Member: and then a trial opens up does he just jump to the trial? Doctor: No. Oh, you got to date it, Sorry. Patient: Oh, I’m sorry. Doctor: I can’t even date it for you. It has to be you. Yeah. Um, Uh, If it’s working we don’t bail out, only if it’s not working, but we will have, you know, the trials are like a moving target so if there’s something that pops up and I think that you would benefit then yes, we would make that opportunity. So, I’m always aware of what’s up here which is why I pulled you guys back to say there’s nothing here that is anything other than chemo but now as we’re thinking about this I’ll know, you know, by this week, okay, that’s a lie because this is Thursday, Family Member: It’s Thursday Doctor: by next week, what two trials make sense based on you know what’s happening. You know, the hard part about those chemo trials is there is a group that only gets the chemo. I like that because everybody gets chemo. Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that.
